I'll so possess him with it, that the rest
Of his starved clients shall be banished, all;
And only you received. But come not, sir,
Until I send, for I have something else
To ripen, for your good (You must not know't)

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: But do not you forget to send, now.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Fear not.
Where are you, wife? my Celia? wife? what, blubbering?
Come, dry those tears. I think, thou thoughtest me in earnest?
Ha? by this light, I talked so but to try thee.
Methinks , the lightness of the occasion
Should ha' confirmed thee. Come, I am not jealous.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Faith, I am not, ay, nor never was:
It is a poor, unprofitable humour.
Do not I know, if women have a will,
They'll do 'gainst all the watches, of the world?
And that the fiercest spies, are tamed with gold?
Tut, I am confident in thee, thou shalt see't:
And see, I'll give thee cause too, to believe it.
Come, kiss me. Go, and make thee ready straight,
In all thy best attire, thy choicest jewels,
put 'em all on, and, with 'em, thy best looks:
We are invited to a solemn feast,
At old Volpone's, where it shall appear
How far I am free, from jealousy, or fear.
I fear, I shall begin to grow in love
With my dear self, and my most prosperous parts,
They do so spring, and burgeon; I can feel
A whimsy i' my blood: (I know not how)
Success hath made me wanton. I could skip
Out of my skin, now, like a subtle snake,
I am so limber. O! your parasite
Is a most precious thing, dropped from above,
Not bred 'mongst clods, and clot-polls, here on earth.
I muse, the mystery was not made a science,
It is so liberally professed! almost
All the wise world is little else, in nature,
But parasites, or sub-parasites. And, yet,
I mean not those, that have your bare town-art,
To know, who's fit to feed 'em; have no house,
No family, no care, and therefore mould
Tales for men's ears, to bait that sense; or get
Kitchen-invention, and some stale receipts
To please the belly, and the groin; nor those,
With their court-dog-tricks, that can fawn, and fleer,
Make their revenue out of legs, and faces,
Echo mylord, and lick away a moth:
But your fine, elegant rascal, that can rise,
And stoop (Almost together) like an arrow;
Shoot through the air, as nimbly as a star;
Turn short, as doth a swallow; and be here,
And there, and here, and yonder, all at once;
Present to any humour, all occasion;
And change a visor, swifter, than a thought!
This is the creature, had the art born with him;
Toils not to learn it, but doth practise it
Out of most excellent nature: and such sparks,
Are the true parasites, others but their zanies.
Who's this? Bonario? old Corbaccio's son?
The person I was bound to seek. Fair sir,
You are haply met.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: That cannot be, by thee.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why, sir?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Nay pray thee know thy way, and leave me:
I would be loath to interchange discourse,
With such a mate, as thou art.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Courteous sir,
Scorn not my poverty.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Not I, by heaven:
But thou shalt give me leave to hate thy baseness.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Baseness?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Ay, answer me, is not thy sloth
Sufficient argument? thy flattery?
Thy means of feeding?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Heaven, be good to me.
These imputations are too common, sir,
And easily stuck on virtue, when she's poor;
You are unequal to me, and howe'er
Your sentence may be righteous, yet you are not,
That ere you know me, thus, proceed in censure:
St. Mark bear witness 'gainst you, 'tis inhumane.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What? does he weep? the sign is soft, and good!
I do repent me, that I was so harsh.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: 'Tis true, that, swayed by strong necessity,
I am enforced to eat my careful bread
With too much obsequy; 'tis true, beside,
That I am fain to spin mine own poor raiment,
Out of my mere observance, being not born
To a free fortune: but that I have done
Base offices, in rending friends asunder,
Dividing families, betraying counsels,
Whispering false lies, or mining men with praises,
Trained their credulity with perjuries,
Corrupted chastity, or am in love
With mine own tender ease, but would not rather
Prove the most rugged, and laborious course,
That might redeem my present estimation;
Let me here perish, in all hope of goodness.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: This cannot be a personated passion!
I was to blame, so to mistake thy nature;
Pray thee forgive me: and speak out thy business.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, it concerns you; and though I may seem,
At first, to make a main offence, in manners,
And in my gratitude, unto my master,
Yet, for the pure love, which I bear all right,
and hatred of the wrong, I must reveal it.
This very hour, your father is in purpose
To disinherit you —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And thrust you forth,
As a mere stranger to his blood; 'tis true, sir:
The work no way engageth me, but, as
I claim an interest in the general state
Of goodness, and true virtue, which I hear
T'abound in you: and, for which mere respect,
Without a second aim, sir, I have done it.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: This tale hath lost thee much of the late trust,
Thou hadst with me; it is impossible:
I know not how to lend it any thought,
My father should be so unnatural.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It is a confidence, that well becomes
Your piety; and formed (No doubt) it is,
From your own simple innocence: which makes
Your wrong more monstrous, and abhorred. But, sir,
I now, will tell you more. This very minute,
It is, or will be doing: and, if you
Shall be but pleased to go with me, I'll bring you,
(I dare not say where you shall see, but) where
Your ear shall be a witness of the deed;
Hear yourself written bastard: and professed
The common issue of the earth.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I'm mazed!

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, if I do it not, draw your just sword,
And score your vengeance, on my front, and face;
Mark me your villain: you have too much wrong,
And I do suffer for you, sir. My heart
Weeps blood, in anguish —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Lead. I follow thee.
Mosca stays long, methinks . Bring forth your sports
And help, to make the wretched time more sweet.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Dwarf, fool, and eunuch, well met here we be.
A question it were now, whether of us three,
Being all the known delicates of a rich man,
In pleasing him, claim the precedency can?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I claim for myself.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: And, so doth the fool.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: 'Tis foolish indeed: let me set you both to school.
First, for your dwarf, he's little, and witty,
And every thing, as it is little, is pretty;
else why do men say to a creature of my shape,
So soon as they see him, it's a pretty little ape?
And, why a pretty ape? but for pleasing imitation
Of greater men's action, in a ridiculous fashion.
Beside, this feat body of mine doth not crave
Half the meat, drink, and cloth, one of your bulks will have.
Admit, your fool's face be the mother of laughter,
Yet, for his brain, it must always come after:
And, though that do feed him, it's a pitiful case,
His body is beholding to such a bad face.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Who's there?one knocks. my couch, away, look, Nano, see:
Give me my caps, first — go, inquire. Now, Cupid
Send it be Mosca, and with fair return.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: It is the beauteous madam —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Would-be — is it?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Now, torment on me; squire her in:
For she will enter, or dwell here for ever.
Nay, quickly, that my fit were passed. I fear
A second hell too, that my loathing this
Will quite expel my appetite to the other:
Would she were taking, now, her tedious leave.
Lord, how it threats me, what I am to suffer!
I thank you, good sir. Pray you signify
Unto your patron, I am here. This band
Shows not my neck enough (I trouble you, sir,
Let me request you, bid one of my women
Come hither to me) in good faith, ay, am dressed
Most favourably, today, it is no matter,
'Tis well enough. Look, see, these petulant things!
How they have done this!

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I do feel the fever
Entering, in at mine ears; o, for a charm,
To fright it hence.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Come nearer: is this curl
In his right place? or this? why is this higher
Than all the rest? you ha' not washed your eyes, yet?
Or do they not stand even i'your head?
Where's your fellow? call her.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Now, st. Mark
Deliver us: anon, she'll beat her women,
Because her nose is red.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I pray you, view
This tire, forsooth: are all things apt, or no?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: One hair a little, here, stick out, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Does 't so forsooth? and where was your dear sight
When it did so, forsooth? what now? bird-eyed?
And you, too? Pray you both approach, and mend it.
Now (By that light) I muse, you're not ashamed!
Ay, that have preached these things, so oft, unto you,
Read you the principles, argued all the grounds,
Disputed every fitness, every grace,
Called you to counsel of so frequent dressings —

sp.speaker: (Nan.
sp.l: More carefully, then of your fame, or honour)

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Made you acquainted, what an ample dowry
The knowledge of these things would be unto you,
Able, alone, to get you noble husbands
At your return: and you, thus, to neglect it?
Besides, you seeing what a curious nation
Th'italians are, what will they say of me?
The English lady cannot dress herself;
Here's a fine imputation, to our country!
Well, go your ways, and stay, i'the next room.
This fucus was too course too, it's no matter.
Good-sir, you'll give 'em entertainment?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The storm comes towards me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: How does my Volp?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Troubled with noise, I cannot sleep; I dreamt
That a strange fury entered, now, my house,
And, with the dreadful tempest of her breath,
Did cleave my roof asunder.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Believe me, and I
Had the most fearful dream, could I remember't —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Out on my fate; I ha' given her the occasion
How to torment me: she will tell me hers.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Methought , the golden mediocrity
Polite, and delicate —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, if you do love me,
No more; I sweat, and suffer, at the mention
Of any dream: feel, how I tremble yet.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Alas, good soul! the passion of the heart.
Seed-pearl were good now, boiled with syrup of apples,
Tincture of gold, and coral, citron-pills,
Your elicampane root, mirobalanes —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Ay me, I have ta'en a grasshopper by the wing.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Burned silk, and amber, you have muscadel
Good i'the house —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: You will not drink, and part?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No, fear not that. I doubt, we shall not get
Some English saffron (Half a dram would serve)
Your sixteen cloves, a little musk, dried mints.
Buglosse, and barley-meal —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: She's in again,
Before I feigned diseases, now I have one.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: And these applied, with a right scarlet-cloth —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Another flood of words! A very torrent!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Shall I, sir, make you a poultice?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: No, no, no;
I'm very well: you need prescribe no more.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I have, a little, studied physic; but, now,
I'm all for music: save, i'the forenoons,
An hour, or two, for painting. I would have
A lady, indeed, t'have all, letters, and arts,
Be able to discourse, to write, to paint,
But principal (As Plato holds) your music
(And, so does wise Pythagoras, I take it)
Is your true rapture; when there is consent
In face, in voice, and clothes: and is, indeed,
Our sex's chiefest ornament.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The poet,
As old in time, as Plato, and as knowing,
Says that your highest female grace is silence.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Which o'your poets? Petrarch? or Tasso? or Dante?
Guarini? Ariosto? Aretine?
Cieco di Hadria? I have read them all.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Is every thing a cause, to my destruction?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I think, I ha' two or three of'hem, about me.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The sun, the sea will sooner, both, stand still,
Than her eternal tongue! nothing can scape it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Here's pastor fido —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Profess obstinate silence,
That's, now, my safest.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: All our English writers,
I mean such, as are happy in th'italian,
Will deign to steal out of this author, mainly;
Almost as much, as from Montaigne:
He has so modern, and facile a vein,
Fitting the time, and catching the court-ear.
Your Petrarch is more passionate, yet he,
In days of sonetting, trusted 'em, with much:
Dante is hard, and few can understand him.
But, for a desperate wit, there's Aretine!
Only, his pictures are a little obscene —
You mark me not?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Alas, my mind's perturbed.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Why, in such cases, we must cure ourselves,
Make use of our philosophy —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O'y me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: And, as we find our passions do rebel,
Encounter 'em with reason; or divert 'em,
By giving scope unto some other humour
Of lesser danger: as, in politic bodies,
There's nothing, more, doth overwhelm the judgement,
And clouds the understanding, then too much
Settling, and fixing, and (As't were) subsiding
Upon one object. For the incorporating
of these same outward things, into that part,
Which we call mental, leaves some certain faeces,
That stop the organs, and, as Plato says,
Assassinates our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Now, the spirit
Of patience help me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Come, in faith, I must
Visit you more, a days; and make you well:
Laugh, and be lusty.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: My good angel save me.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: There was but one sole man, in all the world,
With whom I ere could sympathize; and he
Would lie you often, three, four hours together,
To hear me speak: and be (Sometime) so rapt,
As he would answer me, quite from the purpose,
Like you, and you are like him, just. I'll discourse
(And 't be but only, sir, to bring you asleep
How we did spend our time, and loves, together,
For some six years.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, o, o, o, o, o.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: For we were coaetanci, and brought up —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Some power, some fate, some fortune rescue me.
God save you, madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Mosca? welcome,
Welcome to my redemption.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why, sir?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O,
Rid me of this my torture, quickly, there;
My madam, with the everlasting voice:
The bells, in time of pestilence, never made
Like noise, or were in that perpetual motion;
The cockpit comes not near it. All my house,
But now, steamed like a bath, with her thick breath.
A lawyer could not have been heard; nor scarce
Another woman, such a hail of words
She has let fall. For hell's sake, rid her hence.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Has she presented?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, I do not care,
I'll take her absence, upon any price,
With any loss.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Madam —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I ha' brought your patron
A toy, a cap here, of mine own work —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: 'Tis well,
I had forgotten to tell you, I saw your knight,
Where you'd little think it —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Marry,
Where yet, if you make haste, you may apprehend him,
Rowing upon the water in a gondole,
With the most cunning courtesan, of Venice.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Is't true?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Pursue 'em, and believe your eyes:
Leave me, to make your gift. I knew, 't would take.
For lightly, they that use themselves most licence,
Are still most jealous.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Mosca, hearty thanks,
For thy quick fiction, and delivery of me.
Now, to my hopes, what sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: But do you hear, sir? —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Again; I fear a paroxysm.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Which way
Rowed they together?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Towards the Rialto.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I pray you lend me your dwarf.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I pray you, take him.
Your hopes, sir, are like happy blossoms, fair,
And promise timely fruit, if you will stay
But the maturing; keep you, at your couch,
Corbaccio will arrive straight, with the will:
When he is gone, I'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: My blood,
My spirits are returned; I am alive:
And like your wanton gamester, at primero,
Whose thought had whispered to him, not go less,
Methinks I lie, and draw — for an encounter.
Sir, here concealed, you may hear all. But pray you
Have patience,one knocks. sir; the same's your father, knocks:
I am compelled, to leave you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Do so. Yet,
Cannot my thought imagine this a truth.

div.head: Act. iii. Scene. Vii.

sp.l: Death on me! you are come too soon, what meant you?
Did not I say, I would send?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Yes, but I feared
You might forget it, and then they prevent us.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Prevent? did ere man haste so, for his horns?
A courtier would not ply it so, for a place.
Well, now there's no helping it, stay here;
I'll presently return.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Where are you, Celia?
You know not wherefore I have brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not well, except you told me.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Now, I will:
Hark hither.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir,to Bonario. your father hath sent word,
It will be half an hour, ere he come;
And therefore, if you please to walk, the while,
Into that gallery — at the upper end,
There are some books, to entertain the time:
and I'll take care, no man shall come unto you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Yes, I will stay there, I do doubt this fellow.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: There, he is far enough; he can hear nothing:
And, for his father, I can keep him off.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Nay, now, there is no starting back; and therefore,
Resolve upon it: I have so decreed.
It must be done. Nor, would I move't afore,
Because I would avoid all shifts and tricks,
That might deny me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, let me beseech you,
Affect not these strange trials; if you doubt
My chastity, why lock me up, for ever:
Make me the heir of darkness. Let me live,
Where I may please your fears, if not your trust.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Believe it, I have no such humour, I.
All that I speak, I mean; yet I am not mad:
Not horn-mad, see you? Go too, show yourself
Obedient, and a wife.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I say it,
Do so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Was this the train?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I've told you reasons;
What the physicians have set down; how much,
It may concern me; what my engagements are;
My means; and the necessity of those means,
For my recovery: wherefore, it you be
Loyal, and mine, be won, respect my venture.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Before your honour?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Honour? tut, a breath;
There's no such thing, in nature: a mere term
Invented to awe fools. What is my gold
The worse, for touching? clothes, for being looked on?
Why, this is no more. An old, decrepit wretch,
That has no sense, no sinew; takes his meat
With others fingers; only knows to gape,
When you do scald his gums; a voice; a shadow;
And, what can this man hurt you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Lord! what spirit
Is this hath entered him?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: And for your fame,
That's such a jig; as if I would go tell it,
Cry it, on the piazza! who shall know it?
But he, that cannot speak it; and this fellow,
Whose lips are i' my pocket: save yourself,
If you'll proclaim't, you may. I know no other,
Should come to know it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are heaven, and saints then nothing?
Will they be blind, or stupid?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good sir,
Be jealous still, emulate them; and think
What hate they burn with, towards every sin.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I grant you: if I thought it were a sin,
I would not urge you. Should I offer this
To some young Frenchman, or hot Tuscan blood,
that had read Aretine, conned all his prints,
Knew every quirk within lust's labyrinth,
And were professed critic, in lechery;
And I would look upon him, and applaud him,
This were a sin: but here, 'tis contrary,
A pious work, mere charity, for physic,
And honest polity, to assure mine own.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O heaven! canst thou suffer such a change?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Thou art mine honour, Mosca, and my pride;
My joy, my tickling, my delight! go, bring 'em.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Please you draw near, sir.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Come on, what —
You will not be rebellious? by that light —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, signior Corvino, here, is come to see you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And hearing of the consultation had,
So lately, for your health, is come to offer,
Or rather, sir, to prostitute —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Thanks, sweet Mosca.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Freely, unasked, or unentreated —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: (As the true, fervent instance of his love)
His own most fair and proper wife; the beauty,
Only of price, in Venice —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: 'Tis well urged.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: To be your comfortress, and to preserve you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Alas, I am passed already! Pray you, thank him,
For his good care, and promptness, but for that,
'Tis a vain labour, e'en to fight, 'gainst heaven;
Applying fire to a stone: (Uh, uh, uh, uh.)
Making a dead leaf grow again. I take
His wishes gently, though; and, you may tell him,
What i' have done for him: marry; my state is hopeless!
Will him, to pray for me; and t'use his fortune,
With reverence, when he comes to't.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir?
Go to him, with your wife.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Heart of my father!
Wilt thou persist thus? come, I pray thee, come.
Thou seest 'tis nothing. Celia. By this hand,
I shall grow violent. Come, do't, I say.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Sir, kill me, rather: I will take down poison,
Eat burning coals, do any thing —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Be damned.
(Heart) I will drag thee hence, home, by the hair;
Cry thee a strumpet, through the streets; rip up
Thy mouth, unto thine ears; and slit thy nose,
Like a raw rotchet — do not tempt me, come.
Yield, I am loath — (Death) I will buy some slave,
Whom I will kill, and bind thee to him, alive;
And at my window, hang you forth: devising
Some monstrous crime, which I, in capital letters,
Will eat into thy flesh, with aquafortis,
and burning corrosives, on this stubborn breast.
Now, by the blood, thou hast incensed, I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir, what you please, you may, I am your martyr.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Be not thus obstinate. I ha' not deserved it:
Think, who it is, entreats you. Pray thee, sweet;
(Good faith) thou shalt have jewels, gowns, attires,
What thou wilt think, and ask. Do, but, go kiss him.
Or touch him, but. For my sake. At my suit.
This once. No? not? I shall remember this.
Will you disgrace me, thus? do you thirst my undoing?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Nay, gentle lady, be advised.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: No, no.
She has watched her time. God's precious, this is scurvy;
'Tis very scurvy: and you are —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Nay, good, sir.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: An errant locust, by heaven, a locust. Whore,
Crocodile, that hast thy thy tears prepared,
Expecting, how thou'lt bid 'em flow.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Nay, pray you, sir,
She will consider.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Would my life would serve
To satisfy.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: ('sdeath) if she would but speak to him,
And save my reputation, 'twere somewhat;
But, spitefully to affect my utter ruin.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Ay, now you have put your fortune, in her hands.
Why i'faith, it is her modesty, I must quit her;
If you were absent, she would be more coming;
I know it: and dare undertake for her.
What woman can, before her husband? Pray you,
Let us depart, and leave her, here.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Sweet Celia,
Thou mayst redeem all, yet; I'll say no more:
If not, esteem yourself as lost. Nay, stay there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O god, and his good angels! whether, whether.
Is shame fled humane breasts? that with such ease,
Men dare put off your honours, and their own?
Is that, which ever was a cause of life,
Now placed beneath the basest circumstance?
And modesty an exile made, for money?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: he leaps off from his couch. ay, in Corvino, and such earth-fed minds,
That never tasted the true heaven of love.
Assure thee, Celia, he that would sell thee,
Only for hope of gain, and that uncertain,
He would have sold his part of paradise
For ready money, had he met a copeman.
Why art thou mazed, to see me thus revived?
Rather applaud thy beauty's miracle;
'Tis thy great work: that hath, not now alone,
But sundry times, raised me, in several shapes,
And, but this morning, like a mountebank,
to see thee at thy window. Ay, before
I would have left my practice, for thy love,
In varying figures, I would have contended
With the blue Proteus, or the horned flood.
Now, art thou welcome.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sir!

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Nay, fly me not.
Nor, let thy false imagination
That I was bedrid, make thee think, I am so:
Thou shalt not find it. I am, now, as fresh,
As hot, as high, and in as jovial plight,
As when (In that so celebrated scene,
At recitation of our comedy,
For entertainment of the great Valois)
I acted young Antinous; and attracted
The eyes, and ears of all the ladies, present,
To admire each graceful gesture, note, and footing.

div.l: Come, my Celia, let us prove,
While we can, the sports of love;
Time will not be ours, for ever,
He, at length, our good will sever;
Spend not then his gifts, in vain.
Suns, that set, may rise again:
But if, once, we lose this light,
'Tis with us perpetual night.
Why should we defer our joys?
Fame, and rumor are but toys.
Cannot we delude the eyes
Of a few poor household-spies?
Or his easier ears beguile,
Thus removed, by our wile?
'Tis no sin, loves fruits to steal;
But the sweet thefts to reveal:
To be taken, to be seen,
These have crimes accounted been.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Some serene blast me, or dire lightning strike
This my offending face.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Why droops my Celia?
Thou hast in place of a base husband, found
A worthy lover: use thy fortune well,
With secrecy, and pleasure. See, behold,
What thou art Queen of; not in expectation,
As I feed others: but possessed, and crowned.
See, here, a rope of pearl; and each, more orient
Than that the brave Egyptian Queen caroused:
dissolve, and drink 'em. See, a carbuncle,
May put out both the eyes of our st. Mark;
A diamant, would have bought Lollia Paulina,
When she came in, like starlight hid with jewels,
That were the spoils of provinces; take these,
And wear, and lose 'em: yet remains an earring
To purchase them again, and this whole state.
A gem, but worth a private patrimony,
Is nothing: we will eat such at a meal.
The heads of parrots, tongues of nightingales,
The brains of peacocks, and of ostriches
Shall be our food: and, could we get the phoenix,
(Though nature lost her kind) she were our dish.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good sir, these things might move a mind affected
With such delights; but I, whose innocence
Is all I can think wealthy, or worth th'enjoying,
And which once lost, I have naught to lose beyond it,
Cannot be taken with these sensual baits:
If you have conscience —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: 'Tis the beggar's virtue,
If thou hast wisdom, hear me, Celia.
Thy baths shall be the juice of july-flowers,
Spirit of roses, and of violets,
The milk of unicorns, and panther's breath
Gathered in bags, and mixed with Cretan wines.
Our drink shall be prepared gold, and amber;
Which we will take, until my roof whirl round
With the vertigo: and my dwarf shall dance,
My eunuch sing, my fool make up the antique.
Whilst, we, in changed shapes, act Ovid's tales,
Thou, like Europa now, and I like Jove,
Than I like Mars, and thou like Erycine,
So, of the rest, till we have quite run through
And wearied all the fables of the gods.
Then will I have thee in more modern forms,
Attired like some sprightly dame of France,
Brave Tuscan lady, or proud Spanish beauty;
Sometimes, unto the Persian sophy's wife;
Or the grand-signiors mistress; and, for change,
To one of our most artful courtesans,
Or some quick negro, or cold Russian;
And I will meet thee, in as many shapes:
Where we may, so, transfuse our wand'ring souls,
Out at our lips, and score up sums of pleasures,
That the curious shall not know,
How to tell them, as they slow;
and the envious, when they find
What their number is, be pinned.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If you have ears that will be pierced; or eyes,
That can be opened; a heart, may be touched;
Or any part, that yet sounds man, about you:
If you have touch of holy saints, or heaven,
Do me the grace, to let me scape. If not,
Be bountiful, and kill me. You do know,
I am a creature, hither ill betrayed,
By one, whose shame I would forget it were,
If you will deign me neither of these graces,
Yet feed your wrath, sir, rather than your lust;
(It is a vice, comes nearer manliness)
And punish that unhappy crime of nature,
Which you miscall my beauty: flay my face,
Or poison it, with ointments, for seducing
Your blood to this rebellion. Rub these hands,
With what may cause an eating leprosy,
E'en to my bones, and marrow: any thing,
That may disfavour me, save in my honour.
And I will kneel to you, pray for you, pay down
A thousand hourly vows, sir, for your health,
Report, and think you virtuous —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Think me cold,
Frozen, and impotent, and so report me?
That I had Nestor's hernia, thou wouldst think.
I do degenerate, and abuse my nation,
To play with opportunity, thus long:
I should have done the act, and then have parleyed.
Yield, or I'll force thee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O! just God.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: In vain —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Forbear,he 〈◊〉 from 〈◊〉 Mosca 〈◊〉 placed 〈◊〉 foul ravisher, libidinous swine,
Free the forced lady, or thou diest, impostor.
But that I am loath to snatch thy punishment
Out of the hand of justice, thou shouldst, yet,
Be made the timely sacrifice of vengeance,
Before this altar, and this dross, thy idol.
Lady, let's quit the place, it is the den
Of villainy; fear naught, you have a guard:
And he, ere long, shall meet his just reward.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Fall on me, roof, and bury me in ruin,
Become my grave, that wert my shelter. O!
I am unmasked, unspirited, undone,
Betrayed to beggary, to infamy —
Where shall I run, most wretched shame of men,
To beat out my unlucky brains?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Here, here.
What! dost thou bleed?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, that his well-driven sword
Had been so courteous to have cleft me down,
Unto the navel; ere I lived to see
My life, my hopes, my spirits, my patron, all
Thus desperately engaged, by my error.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Woe, on thy fortune.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And my follies, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Th' hast made me miserable.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And myself, sir.
Who would have thought, he would have hearkened, so?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I know not, if my heart
Could expiate the mischance, I'd pluck it out.
Will you be pleased to hang me? or cut my throat?
And I'll requite you, sir. Let's die like Romans,
they knock without. since we have lived, like Grecians.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Hark, who's there?
I hear some footing, officers, the saffi,
Come to apprehend us! I do feel the brand
Hissing already, at my forehead: now,
Mine ears are boring.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: To your couch, sir, you
Make that place good, however . Guilty men
Suspect, what they deserve still. Signior Corbaccio!
Why! how now? Mosca!

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, undone, amazed, sir.
Your son (I know not, by what accident)
Acquainted with your purpose to my patron,
Touching your will, and making him your heir;
Entered our house with violence, his sword drawn,
Sought for you, called you wretch, unnatural,
Vowed he would kill you.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes, and my patron.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: This act, shall disinherit him indeed:
Here is the will.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Right and well.
Be you as careful now, for me.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: My life, sir,
Is not more tendered, I am only yours.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: How does he? will he die shortly, think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I fear.
He'll outlast may.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Today?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: No, last-out may, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Couldst thou not give him a dram?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, by no means, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Nay, I'll not bid you.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: This is a knave, I see.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: How, signior Voltore! did he hear me?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Parasite.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Who's that? O, sir, most timely welcome —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Scarce,
To the discovery of your tricks, I fear.
You are his, only? and mine, also? are you not?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Who? Ay, sir!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: You, sir. What device is this
About a will?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: A plot for you, sir.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Come,
Put not your foist's upon me, I shall scent 'em.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Did you not hear it?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Yes, I hear, Corbaccio
Hath made your patron, there, his heir.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
By my device, drawn to it by my plot,
With hope —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Your patron should reciprocate?
And, you have promised?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: For your good, I did, sir.
Nay more, I told his son, brought, hid him here,
Where he might hear his father pass the deed;
Being persuaded to it, by this thought, sir,
That the unnaturalness, first, of the act,
And then, his fathers oft disclaiming in him,
(Which I did mean t'help on) would sure enrage him
To do some violence upon his parent.
On which the law should take sufficient hold,
And you be stated in a double hope:
Truth be my comfort, and my conscience,
My only aim was, to dig you a fortune
Out of these two, old rotten sepulchres —

sp.speaker: (Volt.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, Mosca.)

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Worth your patience,
And your great merit, sir. And, see the change!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Why? what success?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Most hapless! you must help, sir.
Whilst we expected th'old raven, in comes
Corvino's wife, sent hither, by her husband —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: What, with a present?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: No, sir, on visitation:
(I'll tell you how, anon) and, staying long,
The youth, he grows impatient, rushes forth,
Seizeth the lady, wound's me, makes her swear
(Or he would murder her, that was his vow)
T'affirm my patron to have done her rape:
Which how unlike it is, you see! and, hence,
With that pretext, he's gone, t'accuse his father;
Defame my patron; defeat you —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Where's her husband?
Let him be sent for, straight.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, I'll go fetch him.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Bring him, to the Scrutineo.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: This must be stopped.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, you do nobly, sir.
Alas, 'twas laboured all, sir, for your good;
Nor, was there want of counsel, in the plot:
but fortune can, at any time, o'erthrow
The projects of a hundred learned clerks, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Will't please you sir, to go along?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Patron, go in, and pray for our success.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Need makes devotion: heaven your labour bless.
I told you, sir, it was a plot: you see
What observation is. You mentioned me,
For some instructions: I will tell you, sir,
(Since we are met, here in this height of Venice)
Some few particulars, I have set down,
Only for this meridian; fit to be known
Of your crude traveller, and they are these.
I will not touch, sir, at your phrase, or clothes,
For they are old.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, I have better.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Pardon
I meant, as they are themes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O, sir, proceed:
I'll slander you no more of wit, good sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: First, for your garb, it must be grave, and serious;
Very reserved, and locked; not tell a secret,
On any terms, not to your father; scarce
A fable, but with caution; make sure choice
Both of your company, and discourse; beware,
You never spoke a truth —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Not to strangers,
For those be they you must converse with, most;
Others I would not know, sir, but, at distance,
So as I still might be a faver, in 'em:
You shall have tricks, else, passed upon you, hourly.
And then, for your religion, profess none;
But wonder, at the diversity of all;
And, for your part, protest, were there no other
But simply the laws of th' land, you could content you:
Nic: Machiavel, and monsieur Bodine, both,
Were of this mind. Then, must you learn the use,
And handling of your silver fork, at meals;
The mettle of your glass: (These are main matters,
With your Italian) and to know the hour,
When you must eat your melons, and your figs.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is that a point of state, too?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here it is.
For your Venetian, if he see a man
Preposterous, in the least, he has him straight;
he has: he strips him. I'll acquaint you, sir,
I now have lived here ('tis some fourteen months)
Within the first week, of my landing here,
All took me for a citizen of Venice:
I knew the forms, so well —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And nothing else.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I had read Contarene, took me a house,
Dealt with my Jews, to furnish it with movables —
Well, if I could but find one man, one man,
To mine own heart, whom I durst trust, I would —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What? what, sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Make him rich; make him a fortune:
He should not think, again. I would command it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With certain projects, that I have:
Which, I may not discover.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If I had
But one to wager with, I would lay odds, now,
He tells me, instantly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: One is, (And that
I care not greatly, who knows) to serve the state
Of Venice, with red herrings, for three years,
And at a certain rate, from Rotterdam,
Where I have correspondence. There's a letter,
Sent me from one o'th' states, and to that purpose;
He cannot write his name, but that's his mark.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He is a chandler?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, a cheesemonger.
There are some other too, with whom I treat,
About the same negotiation;
And, I will undertake it: for 'tis thus,
I'll do't with ease, i' have cast it all. Your hoy
Carries but three men in her, and a boy;
And she shall make me three returns, a year:
So, if there come but one of three, I save,
If two, I can defalk. But, this is now,
If my main project fail.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then, you have others?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I should be loath to draw the subtle air
Of such a place, without my thousand aims.
I'll not dissemble, sir, where ere I come,
I love to be considerate; and, 'tis true,
I have, at my free hours, thought upon
Some certain goods, unto the state of Venice,
Which I do call my cautions: and, sir, which
I mean (In hope of pension) to propound
To the great council, then unto the forty,
So to the ten. My means are made already —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, one, that though his place b'obscure,
Yet, he can sway, and they will hear him. He's
A commandadore.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What, a common sergeant?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, such, as they are, put it in their mouths,
what they should say, sometimes: as well as greater.
I think I have my notes, to show you —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Good, sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But, you shall swear unto me, on your gentry,
Not to anticipate —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Ay, sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nor reveal
A circumstance — my paper is not with me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O, but, you can remember, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My first is,
Concerning tinderboxes. You must know,
No family is, here, without it's box.
Now sir, it being so portable a thing,
Put case, that you, or I were ill affected
Unto the state; sir, with it in our pockets,
Might not I go into the arsenal?
Or you? come out again? and none the wiser?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Except yourself, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Go too, then. Ay, therefore,
Advertise to the state, how fit it were,
That none, but such as were known patriots,
Sound lovers of their country, should be suffered
T'enjoy them in their houses: and, even those,
Sealed, at some office, and, at such a bigness,
As might not lurk in pockets.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My next is, how t'inquire, and be resolved,
By present demonstration, whether a ship,
Newly arrived from Soría, or from
Any suspected part of all the Levant,
Be guilty of the plague: and, where they use,
To lie out forty, fifty days, sometimes,
About the Lazaretto, for their trial;
I'll save that charge, and loss unto the merchant,
And, in an hour, clear the doubt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Indeed, sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Or — I will lose my labour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'My faith, that's much.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay, sir, conceive me. 'twill cost me, in onions,
Some thirty liu'res —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Which is one pound sterling.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Beside my waterworks: for this I do, sir.
First, I bring in your ship, 'twixt two brickwalles;
(But those the state shall venture) on the one
I strain me a fair tarpaulin; and, in that,
I stick my onions, cut in halves: the other
Is full of loopholes, out at which, I thrust
The noses of my bellows; and, those bellows
I keep, with waterworks, in perpetual motion,
(Which is the easiest matter of a hundred)
Now, sir, your onion, which doth naturally
Attract th' infection, and your bellows, blowing
The air upon him, will show (Instantly)
By his changed colour, if there be contagion,
or else, remain as fair, as at the first.
Now 'tis known, 'tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You are right, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I would, I had my note.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'faith, so would I:
But, you ha' done well, for once, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Were I false,
Or would be made so, I could show you reasons,
How I could sell this state, now, to the Turk;
Spite of their galleys, or their —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you, sir Poll.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I have 'em not, about me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That I feared.
They 'Are there, sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, this is my diary,
Wherein I note my actions of the day.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you, let's see, sir. What is here? notandum,
A rat had gnawn my spurre-lethers; notwithstanding,
I put on new, and did go forth: but, first,
I threw three beans over the threshold. Item,
I went, and bought two toothpicks, whereof one
I burst, immediately, in a discourse
With a Dutch merchant, about ragion del stato.
From him I went, and paid a moccinigo,
For piecing my silk stockings; by the way,
I cheapened sprats: and at st. marks, I urined.
I'faith these are politic notes!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, I do slip
No action of my life, thus, but I quote it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Believe me it is wise!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay, sir, read forth.
Where should this loose knight be, trow? sure, he's housed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Why, then he's fast.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ay, he plays both, with me:
I pray you, stay. This heat will do more harm
To my complexion, than his heart is worth.
(I do not care to hinder, but to take him)
How it comes of!

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: My master's yonder.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: With a young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: That same's the party!
In man's apparel. Pray you, sir, jog my knight:
I will be tender to his reputation,
However he demerit.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My lady!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: 'Tis she indeed, sir, you shall know her. She is,
Were she not mine, a lady of that merit,
For fashion, and behaviour; and, for beauty
I durst compare —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It seems, you are not jealous,
That dare commend her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay, and for discourse —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Being your wife, she cannot miss that.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Madam,
here is a gentleman, pray you, use him, fairly,
He seems a youth, but he is —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: None?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, one
Has put his face, as soon, into the world —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You mean, as early? but today?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How's this!

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Why in this habit, sir, you apprehend me.
Well, master Would-bee, this doth not become you;
I had thought, the odour, sir, of your good name,
Had been more precious to you; that you would not
Have done this dire massacre, on your honour;
One of your gravity, and rank, besides!
But, knights, I see, care little for the oath
They make to ladies: chiefly, their own ladies.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now, by my spurs (The symbol of my knighthood)

sp.speaker: (Per.
sp.l: Lord! how his brain is humbled, for an oath)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I reach you not.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Right, sir, your polity
May bear it through, thus. Sir, a word with you.
I would be loath, to contest publicly,
With any gentlewoman; or to seem
Froward, or violent (As the courtier says)
It comes too near rusticity, in a lady,
Which I would shun, by all means: and, however
I may deserve from master Would-bee, yet,
T'have one fair gentlewoman, thus, be made
Th'unkind instrument, to wrong another,
And one she knows not, ay, and to persever;
In my poor judgement, is not warranted
From being a solecism in our sex,
If not in manners.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How is this!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sweet madam,
Come nearer to your aim.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Marry, and will, sir.
Since you provoke me, with your impudence,
And laughter of your light land-siren, here,
Your Sporus, your hermaphrodite —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What's here?
Poetic fury, and historic storms!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The gentleman, believe it, is of worth,
And of our nation.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ay, your White-friers nation?
Come, I blush for you, master Would-bee, I;
And am ashamed, you should ha' no more forehead,
Then, thus, to be the patron, or st. George
To a lewd harlot, a base fricatrice,
A female devil, in a male outside.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay,
And you be such a one! I must bid adieu
To your delights. The case appears too liquid.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ay, you may carry't clear, with your state-face!
But, for your carnival concupiscence,
Who here is fled for liberty of conscience,
from furious persecution of the marshal,
Her will I disciple.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This is fine, i'faith!
And do you use this, often? is this part
Of your wits exercise, 'gainst you have occasion?
Madam —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Go to, sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Do you hear me, lady?
Why, if your knight have set you to beg shirts,
Or to invite me home, you might have done it
A nearer way, by far.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: This cannot work you,
Out of my snare.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why? am I in it, then?
Indeed, your husband told me, you were fair,
And so you are; only your nose inclines
(That side, that's next the sun) to the queen-apple.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: This cannot be endured, by any patience.
What's the matter, madam?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: If the senate
Right not my quest, in this; I will protest 'em,
To all the world, no aristocracy.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: What is the injury, lady?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Why, the callet,
You told me of, here I have ta'en disguised.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Who? this? what means your ladyship? the creature
I mentioned to you, is apprehended, now,
Before the senate, you shall see her —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I'll bring you to her. This young gentleman
I saw him land, this morning, at the port.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Is't possible! how has my judgement wandered!
Sir, I must, blushing, say to you, I have erred:
And plead your pardon.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What! more changes, yet?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I hope, ye ha' not the malice to remember
A gentlewoman's passion. If you stay,
In Venice, here, please you to use me, sir —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Will you go, madam?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Pray you, sir, use me. In faith,
The more you see me, the more I shall conceive,
You have forgotten our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This is rare!
Sir Politique Would-bee? no, sir Politique bawd!
To bring me, th●●● acquainted with his wife!
Well, wise sir Pol: since you have practised, thus,
Upon my freshmanship, I'll try your salt-head,
What proof it is against a counterplot.
Well, now you know the carriage of the business,
Your constancy is all, that is required
Unto the safety of it.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Is the lie
Safely conveyed amongst us? is that sure?
Knows every man his burden?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Then, shrink not.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: But, knows the advocate the truth?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, sir,
By no means. I devised a formal tale,
That salved your reputation. But, be valiant, sir.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I fear no one, but him; that, this his pleading
Should make him stand for a coheir —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Co-halter.
Hang him: we will but use his tongue, his noise,
As we do croakers, here.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Ay, what shall he do?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: When we ha' done, you mean?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why, we'll think,
Sell him for mummia. he's half dust already.
to Voltore. do not you smile, to see this buffalo,
How he doth sport it with his head? — i' should
to Corbaccio. if all were well, and past. Sir, only you
Are he, that shall enjoy the crop of all,
And these not know for whom they toil.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Ay, peace.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: to Corvino, then to Voltore again. but you shall eat it. Much! Worshipful sir,
Mercury sit upon your thundering tongue,
Or the French Hercules, and make your language
As conquering as his club, to beat along,
(As with a tempest) flat, our adversaries:
But, much more, yours, sir.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Here they come, ha' done.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I have another witness, if you need, sir,
I can produce.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, I have her.

div.head: Act iv. Scene v.
div.stage: Avocatori, 4. Bonario, Celia, Voltore, Corbaccio, Corvino, Mosca, notario, Commandadori.

sp.l: The like of this the senate never heard of.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: 'Twil come most strange to them, when we report it.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 4.
sp.l: The gentlewoman has been ever held
Of unreproved name.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: So, the young man.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 4.
sp.l: The more unnatural part that of his father.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: More of the husband.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: I not know to give
his act a name, it is so monstrous!

sp.speaker: Avoc. 4.
sp.l: But the impostor, he is a thing created
T'exceed example!

sp.speaker: Avoc.
sp.l: And all after times!

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: I never heard a true voluptuary
Described, but him.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: Appear yet those were cited?

sp.speaker: Nota.
sp.l: All, but the old magnifico, Volpone.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Why is not he here?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Please your fatherhoods,
Here is his advocate. Himself's, so weak,
So feeble —

sp.speaker: Avoc. 4.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: His parasite,
His knave, his pandar: I beseech the court,
He may be forced to come, that your grave eyes
May bear strong witness of his strange impostures.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Upon my faith, and credit, with your virtues,
He is not able to endure the air.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Bring him, however .

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: We will see him.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Fetch him.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Your fatherhoods fit pleasures be obeyed,
But sure, the sight will rather move your pities,
Then indignation; may it please the court,
In the mean time, he may be heard in me:
I know this place most void of prejudice,
And therefore crave it, since we have no reason
To fear our truth should hurt our cause.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: Speak free.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Then know, most honoured fathers, I must now
Discover, to your strangely abused ears,
The most prodigious, and most frontless piece
Of solid impudence, and treachery,
That ever vicious nature yet brought forth
To shame the state of Venice. This lewd woman
(That wants no artificial looks, or tears,
To help the visor, she has now put on)
Hath long been known a close adulteress,
To that lascivious youth there; not suspected,
I say, but known; and taken, in the act;
With him; and by this man, the easy husband,
Pardoned: whose timeless bounty makes him, now,
Stand here, the most unhappy, innocent person,
That ever man's own goodness made accused.
For these, not knowing how to owe a gift
Of that dear grace, but with their shame; being placed
So above all powers of their gratitude,
Began to hate the benefit: and, in place
Of thanks, device t'extirp the memory
Of such an act. Wherein, I pray your fatherhoods,
To observe the malice, yea, the rage of creatures
Discovered in their evils; and what heart
such take, even, from their crimes. But that, anon,
Will more appear. This gentleman, the father,
Hearing of this foul fact, with many others,
Which daily struck at his too-tender ears,
And, grieved in nothing more, than that he could not
Preserve himself a parent (His sons ills
Growing to that strange flood) at last decreed
To disinherit him.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: These be strange turns!

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: The young man's fame was ever fair, and honest.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: So much more full of danger is his vice,
That can beguile so, under shade of virtue.
But as I said (My honoured sires) his father
Having this setled purpose, (By what means
To him betrayed, we know not) and this day
Appointed for the deed; that parricide,
(I cannot style him better) by confederacy
Preparing this his paramour to be there,
Entered Volpone's house (Who was the man
Your fatherhoods must understand, designed
For the inheritance) there, sought his father:
But, with what purpose sought he him, my lords?
(I tremble to pronounce it, that a son
Unto a father, and to such a father
Should have so foul, felonious intent)
It was, to murder him. When, being prevented
By his more happy absence, what then did he?
Not check his wicked thoughts; no, now new deeds:
(Mischief doth ever end, where it begins)
An act of horror, fathers! he dragged forth
The aged gentleman, that had there lain, bedrid,
Three years, and more, out off his innocent couch,
Naked, upon the floor, there left him; wounded
His servant in the face; and, with this strumpet
The stale to his forged practice, who was glad
To be so active, (I shall here desire
Your fatherhoods to note but my collections,
As most remarkable) thought, at once, to stop
His father's ends; discredit his free choice,
In the old gentleman; redeem themselves,
By laying infamy upon this man,
To whom, with blushing, they should owe their lives.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: What proofs have you of this?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Most honoured fathers,
I humbly crave, there be no credit given
To this man's mercenary tongue.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: Forbear.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: His soul moves in his fee.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: O, sir.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: This fellow,
for six sols more, would plead against his maker.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: You do forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Nay, nay, grave fathers,
Let him have scope: can any man imagine
That he will spare his accuser, that would not
Have spared his parent?

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Well, produce your proofs.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would I could forget, I were a creature.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Signior Corbaccio.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: The father.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Has he had an oath?

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What must I do now?

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: Your testimony's craved.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Speak to the knave?
I'll ha' my mouth, first, stopped with earth; my heart
Abhors his knowledge: I disclaim in him.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: But, for what cause?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: The mere portent of nature.
He is an utter stranger, to my loins.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Have they made you to this!

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: I will not hear thee,
Monster of men, swine, goat, wolf, parricide,
Speak not, thou viper.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Sir, I will sit down,
And rather wish my innocence should suffer,
Than I resist the authority of a father.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Signior Corvino.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: This is strange!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: The husband.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Is he sworn?

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: This woman (Please your fatherhoods) is a whore,
Of most hot exercise, more than a partridge,
Upon record —

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Neighs, like a jennet.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: Preserve the honour of the court.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I shall,
And modesty of your most reverend ears.
And, yet, I hope that I may say, these eyes
Have seen her glued unto that piece of cedar;
That fine well-timbered gallant: and that, here,
The letters may be read, through the horn,
That make the story perfect.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Excellent! sir.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: There is no shame in this, now, is there?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Or if I said, I hoped that she were onward
To her damnation, if there be a hell
Greater than whore, and woman; a good Catholic
May make the doubt.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: His grief hath made him frantic.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Remove him,she swoons. hence.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Look to the woman.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Prettily feigned! again!

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Stand from about her.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Give her the air.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: What can you say?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: My wound rare!
(May't please your wisdoms) speaks for me, received
In aid of my good patron, when he missed
His sought-for father, when that well-taught dame
Had her eve given her, to cry out a rape.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O, most laid impudence! Fathers —

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Sir, be silent,
You had your hearing free, so must they theirs.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: I do begin to doubt th' imposture here.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: This woman, has too many moods.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Grave fathers,
She is a creature, of a most professed,
And prostituted lewdness.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Most impetuous!
Unsatisfied, grave fathers!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: May her feignings
Not take your wisdoms: but, this day, she baited
A stranger, a grave knight, with her loose eyes,
And more lascivious kisses. This man saw 'em
Together, on the water, in a gondola.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Here is the lady herself, that saw 'em too,
Without; who, then, had in the open streets
Pursued them, but for saving her knight's honour.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Produce that lady.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Let her come.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: These things,
They strike, with wonder!

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: I am turned a stone!
Be resolute, madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ay, this same is she.
Out, thou chameleon harlot; now, thine eyes
Vie tears with the hyaena: dar'st thou look
Upon my wronged face? I cry your pardons.
I fear, I have (Forgettingly) transgressed
Against the dignity of the court —

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: And been exorbitant —

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: You have not, lady.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: These proofs are strong.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Surely, I had no purpose:
To scandalize your honours, or my sexes.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: We do believe it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Surely, you may believe it.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Madam, we do.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Indeed, you may; my breeding
Is not so course —

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: We know it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: To offend
With pertinacy —

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Such a presence:
No, surely.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: We well think it.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You may think it.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Let her o'ercome. What witnesses have you,
To make good your report?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Our consciences.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And heaven, that never fails the innocent.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: These are no testimonies.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Not in your courts,
Where multitude, and clamour overcomes.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Nay, than you do wax insolent.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Here, here,
Volpone is brought in, as impotent. the testimony comes, that will convince,
And put to utter dumbness their bold tongues.
See here, grave fathers, here's the ravisher,
The rider on men's wives, the great impostor,
The grand voluptuary! do you not think,
These limbs should affect venery? or these eyes
covet a concubine? Pray you, mark these hands.
Are they not fit to stroke a lady's breasts?
Perhaps, he doth dissemble?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: So he does.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Would you ha' him tortured?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I would have him proved.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Best try him, then, with goads, or burning irons;
Put him to the strappado: I have heard,
The rack hath cured the gout, faith, give it him,
And help him of a malady, be courteous.
I'll undertake, before these honoured fathers,
He shall have, yet, as many left diseases,
As she has known adulterers, or thou strumpets.
O, my most equal hearers, if these deeds,
Acts, of this bold, and most exorbitant strain,
May pass with sufferance, what one citizen,
But owes the forfeit of his life, yea fame,
To him that dares traduce him? which of you
Are safe, my honoured fathers? I would ask
(With leave of your grave fatherhoods) if their plot
Have any face, or colour like to truth?
Or if, unto the dullest nostril, here,
It smell not rank, and most abhorred slander?
I crave your care of this good gentleman,
Whose life is much endangered, by their fable;
And, as for them, I will conclude with this,
That vicious persons when they are hot, and fleshed
In impious acts, their constancy abounds:
Damned deeds are done with greatest confidence.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Take 'em to custody, and sever them.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: 'Tis pity, two such prodigies should live.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Let the old gentleman be returned, with care:
I'm sorry, our credulity wronged him.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: These are two creatures!

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: I have an earthquake in me!

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Their shame (Even in their cradles) fled their faces.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: You have done a worthy service to the state, sir,
In their discovery.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: You shall hear, ere night,
What punishment the court decrees upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: We thank your fatherhoods. How like you it?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Rare.
I'd ha' your tongue, sir, tipped with gold, for this;
I'd ha' you be the heir to the whole city;
The earth I'd have want men, ere you want living:
They're bound to erect your statue, in st. marks.
Signior Corvino, I would have you go,
And show yourself, that you have conquered.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It was much better, that you should profess
Yourself a cuckold, thus, then that the other
should have been proved.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Nay, I considered that:
Now, it is her fault.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Then, it had been yours.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: True, I do doubt this advocate, still.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I'faith,
You need not, I dare ease you of that care.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I trust thee, Mosca.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: As your own soul, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Mosca.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Now for your business, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: How? ha' you business?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes, yours, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: O, none else?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: None else, not I.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Be careful then.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Rest you, with both your eyes, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Dispatch it.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Instantly.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: And look, that all,
Whatever, be put in, jewels, plate, moneys,
Householdstuff, bedding, cortines.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Cortine-rings, sir,
Only, the advocates see must be deducted.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: I'll pay him, now: you'll be too prodigal.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, I must tender it.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Two cecchines is well?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: No, six, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: 'Tis too much.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: He talked a great while,
You must consider that, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Well, there's three —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I'll give it him.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Do so, and there's for thee.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Bountiful bones! What horrid strange offence
Did he commit 'gainst nature, in his youth,
Worthy this age? you see, sir, how I work
Unto your ends; take you no notice.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: No,
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: All, is yours; the devil, and all:
Good advocate. Madam, I'll bring you home.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: No, I'll go see your patron.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: That you shall not:
I'll tell you, why. My purpose is, to urge
My patron to reform his will; and, for
The zeal you have shown today, whereas before
You were but third, or, fourth, you shall be now
Put in the first: which would appear as begged,
If you were present. Therefore —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: You shall sway me.
Well, I am here; and all this brunt is past:
I never was in dislike with my disguise,
Till this fled moment; here, 'twas good, in private,
But, in your public, cave, whilst I breathe.
Before god, my left leg 'gan to have the cramp;
And I apprehended, straight, some power had struck me
With a dead palsy: well, I must be merry,
And shake it off. A many of these fears
Would put me into some villainous disease,
Should they come thick upon me: I'll prevent 'em.
Give me a bowl of lusty wine, to fright
This humour from my heart;he drinks. (Hum, hum, hum)
'Tis almost gone, already: I shall conquer.
Any device, now, of rare, ingenious knavery,
That would possess me with a violent laughter,
Would make me up,drinks again. again! So, so, so, so.
This heat is life; 'tis blood, by this time: Mosca!
How now, sir? does the day look clear again?
Are we recovered? and wrought out of error,
Into our way? to see our path, before us?
Is our trade free, once more?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Exquisite Mosca!

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Was it not carried learnedly?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: And stoutly.
Good wits are greatest in extremities.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It were a folly, beyond thought, to trust
Any grand act unto a cowardly spirit:
You are not taken with it, enough, methinks ?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, more, than if I had enjoyed the wench:
The pleasure of all womankind's not like it.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why, now you speak, sir. We must, here be fixed;
Here, we must rest; this is our masterpiece:
We cannot think, to go beyond this.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: True,
Thou hast played thy prize, my precious Mosca.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Nay, sir,
To gull the court —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: And, quite divert the torrent,
Upon the innocent.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes, and to make
So rare a music out of discords —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Right.
That, yet, to me's the strangest! how th' hast born it!
That these (Being so divided amongst themselves)
Should not sent somewhat, or in me, or thee,
Or doubt their own side.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: True, they will not see't.
Too much light blinds 'em, I think. Each of'hem
Is so possessed, and stuffed with his own hopes,
That any thing, unto the contrary,
Never so true, or never so apparent,
Never so palpable, they will resist it —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Like a temptation of the devil.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Right, sir.
Merchant's may talk of trade, and your great signiors
Of land, that yields well; but if Italy
Have any glebe, more fruitful, than these fellows,
I am deceived. Did not your advocate rare?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O (My most honoured fathers, my grave fathers,
Under correction of your fatherhoods,
What face of truth is, here? If these strange deeds
May pass, most honoured fathers —) I had much ado
To forbear laughing.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: 'T seemed to me, you sweat, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: In troth, I did a little.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: But confess, sir,
Were you not daunted?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: In good faith, I was
A little in a mist; but not dejected:
Never, but still myself.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I think it, sir
Now (So truth help me) I must needs say this, sir.
And, out of conscience, for your advocate:
He has taken pains, in faith, sir, and deserved,
(In my poor judgement, I speak it, under favour,
Not to contrary you, sir) very richly —
Well — to be cozened.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: 'Troth, and I think so too,
By that I heard him, in the latter end.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, but before, sir; had you heard him, first,
Draw it to certain heads, then aggravate,
Then use his vehement figures — I looked still,
When he would shift a shirt; and, doing this
Out of pure love, no hope of gain —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: 'Tis right.
I cannot answer him, Mosca, as I would,
Not yet; but for thy sake, at thy entreaty,
I will begin, e'en now, to vex 'em all:
This very instant.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Call the dwarf,
And eunuch, forth.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Castrone, Nano.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Shall we have a jig, now?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: What you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Go,
Straight give out, about the streets, you two,
That I am dead; do it with constancy,
Sadly, do you hear? impute it to the grief
Of this late slander.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: What do you mean, sir?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O,
I shall have, instantly, my vulture, crow,
Raven, come flying hither (On the news)
To peck for carrion, my she-wolf, and all,
Greedy, and full of expectation —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And then to have it ravished from their mouths?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I will ha' thee put on a gown,
And take upon thee, as thou wert mine heir;
Show 'em a will: open that chest, and reach
Forth one of those, that has the blanks. I'll straight
Put in thy name.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It will be rare, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Ay,
When they e'enegape, and find themselves deluded —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: And thou use them skiruily. Dispatch,
Get on thy gown.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: But, what, sir, if they ask
after the body?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Say, it was corrupted.

sp.speaker: Mos
sp.l: I'll say, it stunk, sir; and was fain to have it
Coffined up instantly, and sent away.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Any thing, what thou wilt. Hold, here's my will.
Get thee a cap, a count-book, pen and ink,
Papers afore thee; sit, as thou wert taking
An inventory of parcels: I'll get up,
Behind the curtain, on a stool, and hearken;
Sometime, peep over; see, how they do look;
With what degrees, their blood doth leave their faces!
O, 'twill afford me a rare meal of laughter.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Your advocate will turn stark dull, upon it.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: It will take off his oratory's edge.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: But your clarissimo, old round-back, he
Will crump you, like a hog-louse, with the touch.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: And what Corvino?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, sir, look for him,
Tomorrow morning, with a rope, and a dagger,
To visit all the streets; he must run mad.
My lady too, that came into the court,
To bear false witness, for your worship —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Yes,
And kissed me 'fore the fathers; when my face
Flowed all with oils.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And sweat, sir. Why, your gold
Is such another medicine, it dries up
All those offensive savours! It transforms
The most deformed, and restores 'em lovely,
As 'twere the strange poetical girdle.Cesti●. Jove
Could not invent, to himself, a shroud more subtle,
To pass Acrisius guards. It is the thing
Makes all the world her grace, her youth, her beauty.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I think, she loves me.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Who? the lady, sir?
She's jealous of you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Dost thou say so?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Hark,
There's some already.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Look.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It is the vulture:
He has the quickest sent.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I'll to my place,
Thou, to thy posture.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I am set.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: But, Mosca,
Play the artificer now, torture 'em, rarely.

div.head: Act. v. scene. iii.
div.stage: Voltore, Mosca, Corbaccio, Corvino, lady, Volpone.

sp.l: How now, my Mosca?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Turkey carpets, nine —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Taking an inventory? that is well.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Two suits of bedding, tissue —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Where's the will?
Let me read that, the while.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: So, set me down:
and get you home.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Is he come, now, to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Of cloth of gold, two more —

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Is it done, Mosca?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Of several velvets, eight —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I like his care.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Dost thou not hear?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Ha? is the hour come, Mosca?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Volpone peeps from behind a traverse. ay, now, they muster.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: What does the advocate here?
Or this Corbaccio?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What do these here?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Mosca?
Is his thread spun?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Eight chests of linen —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O,
My fine dame Would-bee, too!

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Mosca, the will,
That I may show it these, and rid 'em hence.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Six chests of diaper, four of damask — there.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Is that the will?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Down-beds, and bolsters —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Rare!
Be busy still. Now, they begin to flutter:
They never think of me. Look, see, see, see!
How their swift eyes run over the long deed,
Unto the name, and to the legacies,
What is bequeathed them, there —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Ten suits of hangings —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Ay, i'their garters, Mosca. Now, their hopes
Are at the gasp.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Mosca the heir!

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: My advocate is dumb, look to my merchant,
He has heard of some strange storm, a ship is lost,
He faints: my lady will swoon. Old glazen-eyes,
He hath not reached his despair, yet.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: All these
Are out of hope, i' am sure the man.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: But, Mosca —

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Two cabinets —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Is this in earnest?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: One
Of ebony. —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Or, do you but delude me?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: The other, mother of pearl — I am very busy.
Good faith, it is a fortune thrown upon me —
Item, one salt of agate — not my seeking.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: A perfumed box — pray you forbear,
You see I am troubled — made of an onyx —

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Tomorrow, or next day, I shall be at leisure,
To talk with you all.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Is this my large hopes issue?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Sir, I must have a fairer answer.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Madam!
Marry, and shall: pray you, fairly quit my house.
Nay, raise no tempest with your looks; but, hark you:
Remember, what your ladyship offered me,
To put you in, an heir; go to, think on't.
And what you said, e'en your best madames did
For maintenance, and, why not you? enough.
Go home, and use the poor sir Pol, your knight, well;
For fear I tell some riddles: go, be melancholic.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, my fine devil!

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Mosca, pray you a word.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Lord! will not you take your dispatch hence, yet?
Methinks (Of all) you should have been th'example.
Why should you stay, here? with what thought? what promise?
Hear you, do not you know, I know you an ass?
And, that you would, most fain, have been a wittol,
If fortune would have let you? that you are
A declared cuckold, on good terms? this pearl,
You'll say, was yours? right: this diamant?
I'll not deny't, but thank you. Much here, else?
It may be so. Why, think that these good works
May help to hide you bad: I'll not betray you,
Although you be but extraordinary,
And have it only in title, it sufficeth.
Go home, be melancholic too, or mad.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Rare, Mosca! how his villainy becomes him!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Certain, he doth delude all these, for me.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Mosca, the heir?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, his four eyes have found it!

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: I' am cozened, cheated, by a parasite-slave;
Harlot, t'hast guled me.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes, sir. Stop your mouth,
Or I shall draw the only tooth, is left.
Are not you he, that filthy covetous wretch,
With the three legs, that here, in hope of prey,
Have, any time this three year, snuffed about,
With your most grovelling nose; and would have hired
Me to the poisoning of my patron? sir?
Are not you he, that have, today, in court,
Professed the disinheriting of your son?
Perjured yourself? Go home, and die, and stink;
If you but croak a syllable, all comes out:
Away and call your porters, go, go, stink.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Excellent varlet!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Now, my faithful Mosca,
I find thy constancy.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Sincere.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: A table
Of porphyry — I mar'le, you'll be thus troublesome.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Nay, leave off now, they are gone.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why? who are you?
What? who did send for you? O'cry you mercy,
Reverend sir! good faith, I am grieved for you,
That any chance of mine should thus defeat
Your (I must needs say) most deserving travels:
But, I protest, sir it was cast upon me,
And I could, almost, wish to be without it,
But, that the will of th' dead, must be observed.
Marry, my joy is, that you need it not,
You have a gift, sir, (Thank your education)
Will never let you want, while there are men,
And malice, to breed causes. Would I had
But half the like, for all my fortune, sir.
If I have any suits (As I do hope,
Things being so easy, and direct, I shall not)
I will make bold with your obstreperous aid,
(Conceive me) for your fee, sir. In mean time,
You, that have so much law, I know ha' the conscience,
Not to be covetous of what is mine.
Good sir, I thank you for my plate: 'twill help
