To set up a young man. Good faith, you look
As you were costive; best go home, and purge, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Bid him, eat lettuce well: my witty mischief,
Let me embrace thee. O, that I could now
Transform thee to a Venus — Mosca, go,
Straight, take my habit of clarissimo;
And walk the streets; be seen, torment 'em more:
We must pursue, as well as plot. Who would
Have lost this feast?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I doubt it will lose them.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O, my recovery shall recover all.
That I could now but think on some disguise,
To meet 'em in: and ask 'em questions.
How I would vex 'em still, at every turn?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, I can fit you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Canst thou?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Yes, I know
One of the commandatori, sir, so like you,
Him will I straight make drunk, and bring you his habit.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: A rare disguise, and answering thy brain!
O, I will be a sharp disease unto 'em.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sir, you must look for curses —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Till they burst;
The fox fares ever best, when he is cursed.
Am I enough disguised?

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All my ambition is to fright him, only.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: If you could ship him away, 'twere excellent.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: To Zant, or to Aleppo?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes, and ha' his
Adventures put i' th' book of voyages,
And his guld story registered, for truth?
Well, gentlemen, when I am in, a while,
And that you think us warm in our discourse,
Know your approaches.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Trust it to our care.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Save you, fair lady. Is sir Poll. within?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I do not know, sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you, say unto him,
Here is a merchant, upon earnest business,
Desires to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I will see, sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you.
I see, the family is all female, here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: He says, sir, he has weighty affairs of state,
That now require him whole, some other time
You may possess him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you say again,
If those require him whole, these will exact him ▪
Whereof I bring him tidings. What might be
His grave affair of state, now? how, to make
Bolognian sausages, here, in Venice, sparing
One o'th' ingredients.

sp.speaker: Vvom.
sp.l: Sir, he says, he knows
By your word, tidings, that you are no statesman,
And therefore, wills you stay.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sweet, pray you return him,
I have not read so many proclamations,
And studied them, for words, as he has done,
But — here he deigns to come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, I must crave
Your courteous pardon. There hath chanced ( today )
Unkind disaster, 'twixt my lady, and me:
And I was penning my apology
To give her satisfaction, as you came, now.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, I am grieved, I bring you worse disaster;
The gentleman, you met at th' port, today,
That told you, he was newly arrived —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ay, was
A fugitive punk?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, sir, a spy, set on you:
And, he has made relation to the senate,
That you professed to him, to have a plot,
To sell the state of Venice, to the Turk.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: For which, warrants are signed by this time ▪
To apprehend you, and to search your study,
For papers —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Alas, sir. I have none, but notes,
Drawn out of playbooks —

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All the better, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And some essays. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, best
Convey yourself into a sugar-chest,
Or, if you could lie round, a frail were rare:
And I could send you, aboard.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, I but talked so,
For discourse' sake,they knock without. merely.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Hark, they are there.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am a wretch, a wretch.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What, will you do, sir?
Ha you never a curren-but to leap into?
They'll put you to the rack, you must be sudden.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, I have an engine —

sp.speaker: (Mer 3.
sp.l: Sir Politique Would-be?

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Where is he?)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That I have thought upon, before time.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: (I shall never endure the torture.)
Marry, it is, sir, of a tortoise-shell,
Fitted, for these extremities: pray you sir, help me.
Here, i' have a place, sir, to put back my legs,
(Please you to lay it on, sir) with this cap,
And my black gloves, I'll lie, sir, like a tortoise,
Till they are gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And, call you this an engine?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Mine own device — good sir, bid my wife's women
they rush in. to burn my papers.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Where's he hid?

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: We must,
And will, sure, find him.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Which is his study?

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: What
Are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'm a merchant, that came here
To look upon this tortoise.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: St. Mark!
What beast is this?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It is a fish.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Come out, here.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, you may strike him, sir, and tread upon him:
He'll bear a cart.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: What, to run over him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: Let's jump, upon him.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Can he not go?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He creeps, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Let's see him creep.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, good sir, you will hurt him.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: (Heart) I'll see him creep; or prick his guts.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: Come out, here.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Pray you sir, (Creep a little)

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Forth.

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Yet further.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Good sir, (Creep)

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: We'll see his legs.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: they pull of the shell and discover him. god's so, he has garters!

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Ay, and gloves!

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Is this
Your fearful tortoise?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now, sir Poll. we are even;
For your next project, I shall be prepared:
I am sorry, for the funeral of your notes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: 'Twere a rare motion, to be seen in Fleetstreet!

sp.speaker: Mer. 2.
sp.l: Ay, i'the term.

sp.speaker: Mer. 1.
sp.l: Or Smithfield, in the fair.

sp.speaker: Mer. 3.
sp.l: Methinks , 'tis but a melancholic sight!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Farewell, most politic tortoise.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Where's my lady?
Knows she of this?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Inquire.
O, I shall be the fable of all feasts;
The freight of the gazetti; shipboy's tale;
And, which is worst, even talk for ordinaries.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: My lady's come most melancholic, home,
And says, sir, she will straight to sea, for physic.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And I, to shun, this place, and climb for ever;
Creeping, with house, on back: and think it well,
To shrink my poor head, in my politic shell.

div.head: Act iv. Scene v.
div.stage: the first, in the habit of a Commandadora: the other, of a clarissimo. Volpone, Mosca.

sp.l: Am I then like him?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: O, sir, you are he:
No man can sever you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: But, what am I?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Before heaven, a brave clarissimo, thou becomest it!
Pity, thou wert not born one.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: If I hold
My made one, 'twill be well.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I'll go, and see
What news, first, at the court.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Do so. My fox
Is out on his hole, and, ere he shall re-enter,
I'll make him languish, in his borrowed case,
Except he come to composition, with me:
Androgino, Castrone, Nano.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Go, recreate yourselves, abroad; go, sport:
So, now I have the keys, and am possessed.
Since he will, needs, be dead, afore his time,
I'll bury him, or gain by him. I'm his heir:
And so will keep me, till he share at least.
To cousin him of all, were but a cheat
Well placed; no man would construe it a sin:
Let his sport pay for't, this is called the foxtrap.
They say, the court is set.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: We must maintain
Our first tale good, for both our reputations.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Why? mine's no tale: my son would, there, have killed me.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: That's true, I had forgotten: mine is, I am sure.
But, for your will, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Ay, I'll come upon him,
For that, hereafter, now his patron's dead.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Signior Corvino! and Corbaccio! sir,
Much joy unto you.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The sudden good,
Dropped down upon you —

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: (And, none knows (How)
From old Volpone, sir.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Out, errant knave.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Let not your too much wealth, sir, make your furious.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Away, thou varlet.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Dost thou mock me?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: You mock the world, sir, did you not change wills?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Out, harlot.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O! belike you are the man,
Signior Corvino? I'faith, you carry it well;
You grow not mad withal: I love your spirit.
You are not overleavened, with your fortune.
You should ha' some would swell, now like a wine-fat,
With such an autumn — did he gi' you all, sir?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Avoid, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Troth, your wife has shown
Herself a very woman: but, you are well,
You need not care, you have a good estate,
To bear it out, sir, better by this chance.
Except Corbaccio have a share?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Hence, varlet.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: You will not be a' known, sir: why 'tis wise.
Thus do all gamesters, at all games, dissemble.
No man will seem to win. Here, comes my vulture,
Heaving his beak up i' the air, and snuffing.
Outstripped thus, by a parasite? A slave?
Would run on errands? and make legs, for crumbs?
Well, what I'll do —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The court stays for you worship.
I e'en rejoice, sir, at your worship's happiness,
And that it fell into so learned hands,
That understand the fingering. —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I mean to be a suitor to your worship,
For the small tenement, out of reparations;
That, at the end of your long row of houses,
By the piscaria: it was, in Volpone's time,
Your predecessor, ere he grew diseased,
A handsome, pretty, customed, bawdy-house,
As any was in Venice (None dispraised)
But fell with him; his body, and that house
Decayed, together.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Come, sir, leave your prating.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Why, if your worship give me but your hand,
That I may ha' the refusal; I have done.
'Tis a mere toy, to you, sir; candle rends:
As your learned worship knows —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: What do I know?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Marry no end of your wealth, sir, god decrease it.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Mistaking knave! what, mockest thou my misfortune?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: His blessing on your heart, sir, would 'twere more.
(Now, to my first, again; at the next corner.)
See, in our habit! see the impudent varlet!

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: That I could shoot mine eyes at him, like gun-stones.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: But, is this true, sir, of the parasite?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Again, t'afflict us? monster?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: In good faith, sir,
I'm heartily grieved, a beard of your grave length
Should be so overreached. I never brooked
That parasites hair, methought his nose should cozen:
There still was somewhat, in his look, did promise
The bane of a clarissimo.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Knave —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Methinks ,
Yet you, that are so traded i' the world,
A witty merchant, the fine bird, Corvino,
That have such moral emblems on your name,
should not have sung you shame; and dropped your cheese:
To let the fox laugh at your emptiness.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Sirrah, you think, the privilege of the place,
And your red saucy cap, that seems (To me)
Nailed to your jolt-head, with those two cecchines,
Can warrant your abuses; come you, hither:
You shall perceive, sir, I dare beat you. Approach.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: No haste, sir, I do know your valour, well:
Since you durst publish what you are, sir.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Tarry,
I'd speak, with you.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Sir, sir, another time —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Nay, now.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O god, sir! I were a wise man,
Would stand the fury of a distracted cuckold.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What!Mosca walks by 'em. come again?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Upon 'em, Mosca; save me,

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: The air's infected, where he breathes.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Let's fly him.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Excellent basilisk! turn upon the vulture.
Well, flesh-fly, it is summer with you, now;
Your winter will come on.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Good advocate,
Pray thee, not rail, nor threaten out of place, thus;
Thou'lt make a solecism (As madam says.)
Get you a biggin, more: your brain breaks loose.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Would you ha' me beat the insolent slave?
Throw dirt, upon his first good clothes?

sp.speaker: Volt,
sp.l: This same
Is, doubtless, some familiar!

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Sir, the court
In troth, stays for you. I am mad, a mule,
That never read Justinian, should get up,
And ride an advocate. Had you no quirk,
To avoid gullage, sir, by such a creature?
I hope you do but jest; he has not done't:
This's but confederacy, to blind the rest.
You are the heir?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: A strange, officious,
Troublesome knave! thou dost torment me.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I know —
It cannot be, sir, that you should be cozened;
'Tis not within the wit of man, to do it:
You are so wise, so prudent, and, 'tis fit,
That wealth, and wisdom still, should go together.

div.head: Act v. scene 10.
div.stage: Avocatoria, 4. Notario, commandadore, Bonario, Celia, Corbaccio, Corvino, Voltore, Volpone.

sp.l: Are all the parties, here?

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.l: All, but the advocate.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: And, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Avo.
sp.l: Then bring 'em forth to sentence.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: O, my most honoured fathers, let your mercy
Once win upon your justice, to forgive —
I am distracted —

sp.speaker: (Volp.
sp.l: What will he do, now?)

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: O,
I know not which t'address myself to, first,
Whether your fatherhoods, or these innocents —

sp.speaker: (Coru.
sp.l: Will he betray himself?)

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Whom, equally,
I have abused, out of most covetous ends —

sp.speaker: (Coru.
sp.l: The man is mad?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What's that!

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: He is possessed.)

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: For which; now struck in conscience, here I prostrate
Myself, at your offended feet, for pardon.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.2.
sp.l: Arise.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O heaven, how just thou art!

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I'm caught
I' mine own noose —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Be constant, sir, naught now
Can help, but impudence.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Speak forward.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: It is not passion in me, reverend fathers,
But only conscience, conscience my good sires,
That makes me, now, tell truth. That parasite,
That knave hath been the instrument of all.

sp.speaker: Avo.
sp.l: Where is that knave? fetch him.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Grave fathers,
This man's distracted; he confessed it, now:
For, hoping to be old Volpone's heir,
Who now is dead —

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Is Volpone dead?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Dead since, grave fathers —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O, sure vengeance!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Stay,
Then, he was no deceiver?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: O, no, none:
The parasite, grave fathers.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: He does speak,
Out of mere envy, 'cause the servant's made
The thing, he gaped for; please your fatherhoods,
This is the truth: though, I'll not justify
The other, but he may be somedeal faulty.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Ay, to your hopes, as well as mine, Corvino:
But I'll use modesty. Pleaseth your wisdoms
To view these certain notes, and but confer them;
As I hope favour, they shall speak clear truth.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: The devil has entered him!

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Or bides in you.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: We have done ill, by a public officer,
To send for him, if he be heir.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: For whom?

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Him, that they call the parasite.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: 'Tis true;
He is a man, of great estate, now left.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Go you, and learn his name; and say, the court
Entreats his presence, here; but, to the clearing
Of some few doubts.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: This same's a labyrinth!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Stand you unto your first report?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: My state,
My life, my fame —

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: (Where is't?)

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Are at the stake.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Is yours so too?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: The advocate's a knave:
And has a forked tongue —

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: (Speak to the point.)

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: So is the parasite, too.

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: This is confusion.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I do beseech your fatherhoods, read but those;

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: And credit nothing, the false spirit hath writ:
It cannot be, but he is possessed, grave fathers.
To make a snare, for mine own neck! and run
My head into it, wilfully! with laughter!
When I had newly 'scaped, was free, and clear!
Out of mere wantonness! O, the dull devil
Was in this brain of mine, when I devised it;
And Mosca gave it second: he must now
Help to sear up this vein, or we bleed dead.
How now! who let you lose? whither go you, now?
What? to buy gingerbread? or to drown kitlings?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Sir, master Mosca called us out of doors,
And bid us all go play, and took the keys.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Did master Mosca take the keys? why, so!
I am farther, in. These are my fine conceits!
I must be merry, with a mischief to me!
What a vile wretch was I, that could not bear
My fortune soberly? I must ha' my crotchets?
And my conundrums! well, go you, and seek him:
His meaning may be truer, than my fear.
Bid him, he straight come to me, to the court;
Thither will I, and, if 't be possible,
Unscrew my advocate, upon new hopes:
When I provoked him, than I lost myself.
These things can ne'er be reconciled. He, here,
Professeth, that the gentleman was wronged;
And that the gentlewoman was brought thither,
Forced by her husband: and there left.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How ready is heaven to those, that pray!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: But, that
Volpone would have ravished her, he holds
Utterly false; knowing his impotence.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Grave fathers, he is possessed; again, I say,
Possessed: nay, if there be possession,
And obsession, he has both.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Here comes our officer.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: The parasite will straight be, here, grave fathers.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: You might invent some other name, sir varlet.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Did not the notary meet him?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Not that I know.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: His coming will clear all.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Yet it is misty.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Volpone whispers the advocate. may't please your father hoods —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Sir, the parasite
Willed me to tell you, that his master lives;
That you are still the man; your hopes the same;
And this was, only a jest —

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Sir, to try
If you were, firm, and how you stood affected.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Art' sure he lives?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Do I live, sir?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: O me!
I was too violent.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Sir, you may redeem it,
They said, you were possessed; fall down, and seem so:
Voltore falls. I'll help to make it good. God bless the man!
(Stop your wind hard, and swell) see, see, see, see!
He vomits crooked pins! his eyes are set,
Like a dead hares, hung in a poulter's shop!
His mouth's running away! do you see, signior?
Now, 'tis in his belly.

sp.speaker: (Coru.
sp.l: Ay, the devil!)

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Now, in his throat.

sp.speaker: (Coru.
sp.l: Ay, I perceive it plain.)

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: 'Twill out, 'twill out; stand clear. See, where it flies!
In shape of a blue toad, with a bat's wings!
Do not you see it, sir?

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: What? I think I do.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: 'Tis too manifest.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Look! he comes t'himself!

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Take good heart, the worst is past, sir.
You are dispossessed.

sp.speaker: Avo 1
sp.l: What accident is this?

sp.speaker: Avo.
sp.l: Sudden, and full of wonder!

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: If he were.
Possessed, as it appears, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: He has been, often, subject to these fits,

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Show him that writing, do you know it, sir?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Deny it, sir, forswear it, know it not.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Yes, I do know it well, it is my hand:
but all, that it contains, is false.

sp.speaker: Bon. 3.
sp.l: O practice!

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: What maze is this!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Is he not guilty, then,
Whom you, there, name the parasite?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Grave fathers,
No more then, his good patron, old Volpone.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Why, he is dead?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: O no, my honoured fathers.
He lives —

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: How! lives?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Lives.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: This is subtler, yet!

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: You said, he was dead?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: You said so?

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: I heard so.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Here comes the gentleman make him way.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: A stool.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 4.
sp.l: A proper man! and were Volpone dead,
A fit match for my daughter.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: Give him way.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Mosca, I was almost lost, the advocate
Had betrayed all; but, now, it is recovered:
All's of the hinge again — say, I am living.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: What busy knave is this! most reverend fathers,
I sooner, had attended your grave pleasures,
But that my order, for the funeral
Of my dear patron did require me —

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: (Mosca!)

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Whom I intend to bury, like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Ay, quick, and cousin me of all.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Still stranger!
More intricate!

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: And come about again!

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: It is a match, my daughter is bestowed.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: (Will you gi'me half?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: First, I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I know,
Your voice is good, cry not so loud )

sp.speaker: Avo. 1.
sp.l: Demand
The advocate. Sir, did not you affirm,
Volpone was alive?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Yes, and he is;
This gent'man told me so, (Thou shalt have half.)

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Whose drunkard is this same? speak some, that know him:
I never saw his face. (I cannot now
Afford it you so cheap.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: No?)

sp.speaker: Avo 1.
sp.l: What say you?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: The officer told me.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I did, grave fathers,
And will maintain, he lives, with mine own life.
And, that this creature told me. (I was born,
With all good stars my enemies.)

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Most grave fathers,
If such an insolence, as this, must pass
Upon me, I am silent: 'twas not this,
For which you sent, I hope.

sp.speaker: Avo. 2.
sp.l: Take him away.

sp.speaker: (Volp.
sp.l: Mosca.)

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Let him be whipped.

sp.speaker: (Volp.
sp.l: Wilt thou betray me?
Cousin me?)

sp.speaker: Aoc. 3.
sp.l: And taught to bear himself
Towards a person of his rank.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I humbly thank your fatherhoods.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Soft, soft: whipped?
And lose all that I have? if I confess,
It cannot be much more.

sp.speaker: Avo. 4.
sp.l: Sir, are you married?

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: They'll be allied,he puts off his disguise. anon; I must be resolute:
The fox shall, here, uncase.

sp.speaker: (Mos.
sp.l: Patron.)

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: Nay, now,
my ruins shall not come alone; your match
I'll hinder sure: my substance shall not glue you,
Nor screw you, into a family.

sp.speaker: (Mos.
sp.l: Why, patron!)

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: I am Volpone, and this is my knave;
This, his own knave; this, avarice's fool;
This, a chimaera of wittal, fool, and knave;
And, reverend fathers, since we all can hope
Naught, but a sentence, let's not now despair it.
You hear me brief.

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: May it please your fatherhoods —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: The knot is now undone, by miracle!

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: Nothing can be more clear.

sp.speaker: Avo. 3.
sp.l: Or can more prove
These innocent.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Give 'em their liberty.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Heaven could not, long, let such gross crimes be hid.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: If this be held the high way to get riches,
May I be poor.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 3.
sp.l: This is not the gain, but torment.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: These possess wealth, as sick men possess fevers,
Which, truelier may be said to possess them.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 2.
sp.l: Disrobe that parasite.

sp.speaker: Coru. Mos.
sp.l: Most honoured fathers.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Can you plead ought to stay the course of justice?
If you can, speak.

sp.speaker: Coru. Volt.
sp.l: We beg favour,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And mercy.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: You hurt your innocence, suing for the guilty.
Stand forth; and, first, the parasite. You appear
To have been the chiefest minister, if not plotter,
In all these lewd impostures; and now, lastly,
Have, with your impudence, abused the court,
And habit of a gentleman of Venice,
Being a fellow of no birth, or blood:
For which, our sentence is, first thou be whipped;
Then live perpetual prisoner in our galleys.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: I thank you, for him.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Bane to thy wolvish nature.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Deliver him to the saffi. Thou, Volpone,
By blood, and rank a gentleman, canst not fall
Under like censure; but our judgement on thee
Is, that thy substance all be straight confiscate
To the hospital, of the incurabili:
And, since the most was gotten by imposture,
By feigning lame, gout, palsy, and such diseases,
Thou art to lie in prison, cramped with irons,
Till thou beest sick, and lame indeed. Remove him.

sp.speaker: Volp.
sp.l: This is called mortifying of a fox.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Thou Voltore, to take away the scandal
Thou hast given all worthy men, of thy profession,
Art banished from their fellowship, and our state.
Corbaccio, bring him near. We here possess
Thy son, of all thy state; and confine thee
to the monastery of San' Spirito:
Where, since thou knew'st not how to live well here,
Thou shalt be learned to die well.

sp.speaker: Corb.
sp.l: Ha! what said he?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You shall know anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Avoc.
sp.l: Thou Corvino, shalt
Be straight embarked from thine own house, and rowed
Round about Venice, through the grand canal,
Wearing a cap, with fair, long ass's ears,
In stead of horns: and, so to mount (A paper
Pined on thy breast) to the berlino —

sp.speaker: Coru.
sp.l: Yes,
And, have mine eyes beat out with stinking fish,
Bruised fruit, and rotten eggs — 'tis well. I'm glad,
I shall not see my shame, yet.

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: And to expiate
Thy wrongs done to thy wife, thou art to send her
Home, to her father, with her dowry trebled:
And these are all your judgements.

sp.speaker: (All.
sp.l: Honoured fathers.)

sp.speaker: Avoc. 1.
sp.l: Which may not be revoked. Now, you begin,
When crimes are done, and past, and to be punished,
To think what your crimes are: away with them.
Let all, that see these vices thus rewarded,
Take heart, and love to study 'em. Mischiefs feed
Like beasts, till they be fat, and then they bleed.
The seasoning of a play is the applause.
Now, though the fox be punished by the laws,
He, yet, doth hope there is no suffering due,
For any fact, which he hath done 'gainst you;
If there be, censure him: here he, doubtful, stands.
If not, fare jovially, and clap your hands.

div.p: This comedy was first acted, in the year 1605.

The principal comedians were,
Ric. Burbadge.
Hen. Condel.
Will. Sly..
Joh. Hemings.
Joh. Lowin.
Alex. Cooke.
With the allowance of the master of revels.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
